body: LEAD: George J. Couri, the chairman of Couristan Inc., an importer of floor coverings, died of lung cancer on Tuesday at his home in the Dyker Heights section of Brooklyn. He was 77 years old. title: George Couri, Executive, 77

body: LEAD: UNADORNED homes are rare commodities around Christmastime in Bay Ridge, Bensonhurst and Canarsie. With thousands of plastic Santas and snowmen, armies of toy soldiers and multicolored megawatts of lights decorating block upon block of houses and apartment buildings, no one could accuse these Brooklyn neighborhoods of a lack of holiday cheer.
title: Neighborhoods Santa Has No Trouble Finding

body: LEAD: As some spectators in the courtroom wept, a distraught Brooklyn mother told a judge yesterday how she drowned her colicky infant son in a bathtub while she was suffering from severe postpartum depression. title: Judge Accepts Insanity Plea In '88 Drowning of Infant

body: LEAD: The specially designed truck that rumbled slowly through the narrow streets of Brooklyn Heights one morning this week is part of the process of taking New York City into a new era of recycling. title: New York Starts Required Recycling

body: LEAD: A Family Court judge ordered a woman from Brooklyn held without bail yesterday until her husband surrendered the couple's 4-year-old son. On Sunday, the father took the boy from a hospital in Manhattan, where he was being treated for leukemia, the police said. A Family Court judge ordered a woman from Brooklyn held without bail yesterday
title: Mother Held After Ill Son Disappears

body: LEAD: With New York City facing a garbage crisis, the City Council is expected to approve a bill tomorrow that would make the recycling of newspapers, magazines, cardboard, glass bottles and metal cans mandatory. Under the bill, each household would be required to sort the recyclable materials. The bill raises questions as to how a city as large as
title: Recycling Law's Mechanics: Symphony of Sorting, Maybe
